repnme.cdata!: Nepal - Second Structural Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Structural
            Adjustment Credit Project for Nepal was satisfactory. The
            project achieved most of its objectives, its impact on
            institutional development has been substantial,
            sustainability is likely, and the performance of both the
            Bank and Borrower was satisfactory. Several lessons can
            learned from this project. Given the complexities of
            institution-building in Nepal, it is desirable to: 1) set
            realistic objectives about how rapidly institutions can be
            improved; 2) limit the interventions to essential key
            requirements; and 3) undertake thorough preparation and follow-up.

docna.cdata!:
Nepal - Second Structural Adustment Credit :
            Credit 2046 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Nepal - Second Structural
            Adustment Credit : Credit 2046 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

repnme.cdata!: Nepal - Second Structural Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This Second Structural Adjustment Credit
            is intended to support the next phase of the First
            Structural Adjustment Operation (SAL I). The main objective
            of the program is to accelerate sustained economic growth by
            reorienting the economy towards a path relying more on the
            private sector, and on improved allocation of public and
            financial resources. It consolidates the policies already
            adopted & reinforces the adjustment process by
            additional measures. Policy performance emphasized by SAL I
            thus far has been encouraging. The measures to be supported
            by SAL II will strengthen the ongoing policy reforms,
            notably those aimed at: (i) continued sound macroeconomic
            management; (ii) improved development expenditure
            management; (iii) continued trade liberalization; (iv)
            improved access of farmers to fertilizers & irrigation
            water; and (v) improved financial institutions.
